pros: If you are looking for a place with cultural diversity and that works to promote inclusivity then consider working for Brooklyn College. Many of the departments have individuals that look forward to helping stakeholders in the community to professionally grow and develop. This is not true of all departments, but as always there are few "bad apples" in every bunch.
cons: Outdated and ineffective practices used to support students and staff. In spite of the demand for more online services and degree programs, CUNY fails to deliver. Information on the websites is not as coherent in comparison to their non-public counterparts. Also, the student information system (CUNYFirst, DegreeWorks) and the other online systems are horrible. The product is not really user friendly, the system keeps timing out even with the scheduled maintenance updates.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great facilities and colleagues. Students are incredibly diverse and interested and engaged. If you dont need a full time hob this is a great gig.
cons: Rules for adjuncts are limiting the ability to survive. Even though the pay rate is now quite high the full time employees running the departments play games with how many classes you are teaching to keep you from achieving milestones to receive benefits or job retention.

review_title: They have chill sometimes busy office jobs

review_title: Great Benefits, Senior Management Not so Much
job_title: Higher Education Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
Very good benefits (free health and dental).
Guaranteed raises and cost of living adjustments.
Summer Friday work schedule was amazing (longer hours 4 days a week for Fridays off).
Pension plan OK if you plan on staying long (10+ yrs).
cons:
Low funding in all areas - no money for even basic necessities. Due to this, even high risk areas are not being maintained. Ancillary departments to facilities required to pick up the slack due to crumbling infrastructure and union environment with narrowly defined job descriptions.
Constant micromanagement at the VP level lead to chaos and stress.
Very little communication from CUNY Central Office lead to confusion among management, especially during COVID.
Certain union personnel willing to work as a team to assist, others have a "not my job" attitude, and you have to figure out who these people are and work with / around hem.
HR Benefits Specialist nasty at best. Unwilling to assist or explain questions about benefits.

pros: Great faculty, lots of support
cons: Understaffed, physical infrastructure sometimes in need of repair

review_title: If you like low pay, Water Bugs/Mice, and being mistreated, work at Brooklyn College
pros: Weekends off. Most offices close at 6pm or earlier Monday through Friday. Very nice campus. Employees are nice that are on your level are nice.
cons: Horrible Pay. Don't Value their employees. Could care less if you are a college graduate from their school. Very little room for growth because they rather keep uneducated people in high positions just because they have been there for ever. Take advantage of you when they realize that you are a good employee. Management is very incompetent!

pros: Collaborative environment with friendly staff. Great research facilities and smart students. The experience as a whole was positive. I would recommend Brooklyn College and specifically the Biais Lab in the Biology department. Great gym facilities
cons: Administration is a little frustrating, but that's pretty normal for a college. The salary at a college isn't excellent, but the work itself is incredibly fulfilling. There hasn't been a research assistant at Brooklyn college in the last 20 years, so my position was pretty new for administration. That said, these roles are pretty different each time. They depend on the research lab / department.

review_title: Nice people, okay starting salaries, but no resources, no raises
pros: Motivated, hard-working students.  Nice colleagues. Great benefits.  One of the last defined-benefit pensions available.  Great Provost.  Some supportive Associate Provosts and Deans, some not so much.  Pockets of good leadership.  Very helpful new people in HR.  Could improve orientation processes and training.
cons: Salaries frozen for 7 years, not great to begin with.  No mobility.  No resources. Buildings collapsing.  Dreadful bureaucracy makes accomplishing things very, very difficult.  Lately, problems with curriculum review and enterprise computing have really damaged morale, and it will be years before things recover.  Not having a contract since 2007 has also hurt morale.  Little credit given for innovation, though it does thrive.

pros: The institution offers Flexible Schedule, CA's go though a lot of management training and supervised training. They do receive discounts on and off campus and it's a great way to to represent the college.
cons: There are Limited promotional opportunities as CA's are PT not FT. As this is part of CUNY there is little or no Medical Coverage available and off course the pay sucks.

review_title: Lack of opportunities and office political
pros: Benefits and work life balance for working mom and people who retire  wants to earn extra income. Management seems do not punish the people who is lazy at work compared to private sector.
cons: Easily gets suck of the position forever if the person don't look for outside opportunities. Ambitions for young employees will gone easily. The compensation is low due to the volume of works you do. Some management also take favor of the works that some employees do.

job_title: Adjunct Stockroom Clerk in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The people working are really quite nice, they don't ask too much of you as an adjunct, and are understanding. The students aren't too terrible, as they all know the deal. Also the campus is quite beautiful.
cons: Sometimes things would get disorganized. There was no direct deposit of paychecks, which wasn't really nice. The outlying areas around the campus are not very nice. Low income neighborhood that  doesn't have much in the way of storefronts.

review_title: My experience at Brooklyn College has been satisfactory
pros: Working in a University environment gave me the flexibility I wanted to be able to spend time with my family and have time for some of my other passions. Moreover I was able to build upon my teaching skills and gain more experience. There are good benefits that are made available to all the employees.
cons: The biggest challenge can be the staff. In a university setting there aren't many opportunities for the staff to interact with each other on a daily bases. Therefore, creating friends really comes down to research/teaching interests. Plus getting into the good graces of people.

review_title: Working at the Brooklyn College has been a dream experience.
pros: The pay is decent, if you work all your required hours on time you get your check every two weeks. The staff and the supervisors is one of the best things working at this place. They are very friendly, always there to help, always avialable to answer any questions, share their experience, willingly to teach you, resolve problems you encounter and have your back at all times. You just need to bring in a friendly attitude and create a solid relationship with them. Do your part and things will turn out right. Plus a good word from your co-workers and supervisors can do wonders. The hours are flexible, and if they like your work, attitude, and commitment they can promote you to different departments.
cons: During the Fall, Winter, Spring, and Summer sessions known as "Peak Times" the work can be crazy, stressful ,and time consuming. Sometimes classes and work can have a conflict but it is manageable. But this is a part time position, it is unlikely the position might be converted to full time and the benefits are not that great either. If you work for CUNY they pay for your tuition only if you are full time employee, when thats going to happen as I mentioned above unlikely so forget about the tuition.

pros: Relatively simple work most of the time, a simple part time job if you are simply looking to make a few bucks on the side
cons: Lousy pay, no raises anytime recently, limited amount of hours allowed per week (max 20), and there are some REALLY obnoxious students (who sometimes aren't even students of this college)  who try to walk all over you

pros: Health benefits, even if only part-time.
cons: The bureaucracy for administrators and everyone else alike at Brooklyn College is insane. What should be a simple task becomes a sprawling series of endless tasks - multiplied by however many tasks one receives, this becomes overwhelming. Even as a part-time, low-level administrator, your job is not limited to your own but rather expands to encompass the job duties of whomever around you is salaried (depending on their individual willingness to do their own jobs).

pros: There is quite a lot of variability from area to area, department to department.  I fee like I've lucked out compared to some other folks.  It's a union environment.  This definitely has some negatives, but they are outweighed by the comfortable and stable work environment it creates.
cons: The resources are quite tight and I'm not convinced they are deployed in the most effective way, but overall it's a good place to work.

pros:
Good experience on:
 Research and synthesize market and industry data
 Conduct interview with clients and develop program benchmark and positioning strategies
 Create business plans and generate final documents
 Assist clients seeking business loans through all the stages of the financing process
 Keep tracking of projects and perform administrative tasks as needed
cons:
Low salary
Non press
Too many race staff there
office culture is complicated

pros: Very nice people. Not overly difficult work. Good if you enjoy helping others succeed. Convenient job when you have gaps in your schedule.
cons: Not a sustainable job for the most part. Relatively low pay and short hours means it can't be only source of income. While tutoring for the most part you might either not see anyone or get swamped with multiple students at once.

review_title: It was a rewarding experience with friendly colleagues
pros: The colleagues are Friendly. Professors are Reliable.  The management goes the extra mile to accommodate you in case of an emergency.
cons: The buildings need to be renovated. The technology for the psychology department is not up to date.  Still relie heavily on paper work.

pros: Flexibility with schedule and independence from other areas. Good life / work balance. People are generally helpful.
cons: The process is very bureaucratic. In my experience, position was granted after having a recommendation from staff. Internship did not give a real life experience on my field. Budget and resources are very constrained.

pros: I enjoyed teaching at BC because the department gave me a good amount of freedom for how I wanted to go about instructing the courses.
cons: Unfortunately I found that many of the students were not very interested in learning what was being taught and that they were just in the class to satisfy requirements.

review_title: Great place to work at in beginning but one management changed it became an unpleasant work environment
pros: Meet new people, ability to work independently,
cons: Poor management, no bonuses, poor benefits for PT's, full-time workload given to a part-timer, favoritism at the office, no promotion

pros: Great library, cafeteria, gym and outdoor campus.  First-class faculty in academic and non-academic fields.  Skeptical, rational and humor-laden intellectual atmosphere.
cons:
Building interiors need renovation, especially plumbing, HVAC and classroom desks, chairs and blackboards.

Faculty can be out of step with diverse backgrounds of students.

pros: Union job. Easy to do.
cons: This is specific to the library. No weekly hour guarantee. Cap at 20 hours per week max. At minimum wage you need a second job to pay rent, which is close to impossible because you're not given the same hours each day unless you have seniority of 10+ years.

pros: I was well supported by the staff working at the college in my capacity as a research assistant.
cons: Resources are scarce for professors on campus, and many of them have to share offices which seems odd for a liberal arts college that charges a large tuition.

review_title: Students are great (if you get them to do their work ;)) Administrators are great people, but it's still an institution.
